metadata.title: A Morphological Analyzer for Japanese Nouns, Verbs and Adjectives

sections.text: ar Xiv: 141 0.02 91v2 [cs.CL] 1 6We present an open source morphological analyzer for Japanese nouns, verbs and adjectives.1 The system builds on the morphological analysis capabilities of MeCab [Matsumoto et al., 1999] to integrate finer details of classification such as courtesy, tension, mood and vocal characteristics. We implemented our analyzer in the form of a finite-state transducer using the open-source finite-state compiler FOMA-Toolkit [Hulden, 2009].

sections.heading: 1 Basic Information about Japanese
sections.text: The Japanese language is spoken by more than 100 million speakers (mainly in Japan). It is an agglutination language with an SOV word sequence. The Japanese writing system extensively uses Chinese characters, also known as kanji, along with scripts, hiragana and katakana, which are syllables. There are three main lexical classes in Japanese that have morphology, they are nouns, verbs and adjectives. In Japanese, adjectives are often adjectives with a special morph. As such, it is often not considered a separate word class. In section 4 we will discuss the phenomenon for each of these word classes.

sections.heading: 2 Past Work on the Japanese morphology
sections.text: The lexicon is a list of pairs of words and the corresponding part of the speech. Since Japanese is an unsegmented language, previous work on morphology analyzers of the Japanese language required the use of a segmentator. Often, the segmentation step is performed together with the morphological analysis step in a rule based on [Matsumoto et al., 1991] or the machine learning framework [Kudo et al., 2004, Matsumoto et al., 1999] The current state of Japanese language technology is MeCab2 [Matsumoto et al., 1999], which is expanded by ChaSen3 [Matsumoto et al., 1991] but uses CRFs [Lafferty et al., 2001] instead of HMMs to model these language and morphological sequences.

sections.heading: 3 Available Resources
sections.text: We use MeCab as the pre-processing tool for word segmentation and POS marking. MeCab achieved Fβ values above 0.96 on standard Japanese text corpora segmented and annotated with POS tags. We have collected the following text corpus: (i) Tanaka corpus [Tanaka, 2001] contains 149,909 English-Japanese sentence pairs from various sources such as books, songs, Bibles, etc. These sentences are word segmentations and contain Kana readings for ambiguous kanji characters. However, they do not contain morphological annotations. (ii) Japanese Multilingual Dictionary [Breen, 2004] is a multilingual lexicon database with Japanese as the pivot language. It is updated almost daily and contains a lot of information about lexical elements, such as Kanji / Kana / Romaji readings, part of the language, conjugation group and sensory markers. sections.heading: 4 Survey of Phenomena in Japanese

sections.heading: 4.1 Nouns
sections.text: Nouns are not usually inflected. However, the Japanese language has an extensive honor system, and nouns often adopt courtesy prefixes and suffixes (for animate objects), and a small group of suffixes are also used to refer to collective nouns. Venerable prefixes The prefixes "o" and "go-" are prefixes that are applied to nouns (and sometimes verbs) to convey a respectful or polite tone of speech. Japanese words are preceded by "o," while Chinese-Japanese words are usually preceded by "go-," though there are exceptions in both cases. 4http: / / mecab.googlecode.com / svn / trunk / mecab / doc / posid.html2 of the 11 Honorific suffixes are suffixes that almost always refer to personal names and occasionally other non-human objects (such as animals, which are unrelated suffixes, etc.).

sections.heading: 4.2 Verbs
sections.text: Due to the agglutinative nature of the language, suffixes are relatively productive and in loose language many contractions are used. In general, verbs can be conjugated for aspect, polarity, politeness, mood, voice, tension. Details on verb conjugations are described in § 7.1.3 of 11.

sections.heading: 4.3 Adjectives
sections.text: Japanese has no adjectives in the syntactical sense. Unlike Western languages, where adjectives are usually inflected much like noun declensions, Japanese adjectives are conjugated like a verb. This is because words that behave semantically like adjectives are technically regarded as specialized verbs (i-adjectives) or nominal (na-adjectives). There are some other classes of adjectives that are more commonly used in classical Japanese, and in modern Japanese they are limited to a few special cases. There are two main classes of adjectives: adjective verbs and adjective nouns.

sections.heading: 5 System Design
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.1 High level overview
sections.text: Our morphological analyzer will focus on the task of analyzing the morphology of individual tokens. Therefore, we will design our analyzer to take input from the processed output of MeCab, a high-quality Japanese part of the language tag and morphological analyzer. MeCab is a CRF classifier that segments and marks each token with a part of the language category. It has a hierarchical tag set (of up to 4 levels), starting with 8 broad categories and a total of 68 fine categories. In the case of nouns, it provides a rough morphological analysis by segmenting the morphemes for honorable words and collectivism and classifying them as suffixes or prefixes belonging to persons, places, quantifiers, etc. Consequently, our contribution would be to integrate finer details of the classification such as courtesy and gender attributes as fantasy.

sections.heading: 5.2 Morphological analyzer system details
sections.text: We implement our analyzer by building finite-state converters to process and generate finer analyses. We use Foma5, a popular open-source tool compiler, a programming language, and a C library to create finite-state automatons and converters for NLP applications. Our morphological analyzer will consist of two independent FSTs to handle (i) nouns and (ii) verbs / adjectives that we describe below. 5https: / / code.google.com / p / foma / 4 of 11

sections.heading: 5.3 FSTs for analyzing nouns
sections.text: Japanese nouns have fairly regular conjugations, as such we will design our FST as a converter that uses the part of MeCab's language information as input and translates it into its analyses.From MeCab's output we will have a post-processing script that analyzes MeCab's output and converts it into a format suitable for our analyzers. We will do this with a Python script and segment the input to the FST into separate tokens, so one input could consist of multiple tokens with different attributes. sections.heading: 6 First System Analysis (Nouns)
sections.text: We extracted all types that were labeled as nouns in the Tanaka corpus. Table 1 shows statistics about nouns in the corpus. We randomly selected 1,000 types to manually evaluate and analyze for errors.Table 3 shows some statistics about the nouns that were evaluated. Generally, most nouns in the corpus have no morphology. For nouns that contain morphological elements, our analyzer was able to identify them with high accuracy. However, our analyzer made a few errors (10 in the evaluation set, to be precise), all of which can be traced back to segmentation / tagging errors returned by MeCab, which was unable to properly segment the sentences.

sections.heading: 7 FSTs for analyzing verbs and adjectives
sections.text: Japanese verbs and adjectives are handled very similarly. In fact, most adjectives can be considered a form of specialized verbs and have very similar conjugation rules. Therefore, we will use a single FST to handle these two categories of words.

sections.heading: 7.1 Verb morphology phenomena
sections.text: Lexically, almost every verb in Japanese belongs to one of four conjugation groups: (i) Ichidan verb, (ii) Godan verb, (iii) Sa series irregular conjugations, (iv) Ka series irregular conjugations, (iv) Ka series, (iv) Ka series irregular conjugations, (iv) Japanese verb usually consists of two parts, a stem form and a series of morphemes. The stem form is usually written in kanji together with a kana character that denotes one of the 6 verb forms in 6 of 11 Japanese. Morpheme suffixes are usually written in kana. We refer the user to a comprehensive grammar guide for more information on the stem forms. Here, we will briefly describe the morpheme suffixes treated by our analyzer.

sections.heading: 7.2 Phonological rules
sections.text: As in most languages, there are different phonological rules for conjugated verbs and adjectives. One such frequent and regular rule is the phonological modification of the endings to a [t] consonant. For example, the endings of the te form to -ite, -chite, -rite to a double consonant, -tte, the endings to -bite, -mite, -nite to -ende (intonation of the te syllable), the endings to -kite to -ite and the endings to -gite to -ide (intonation of the te syllable).

sections.heading: 7.3 FST as a generator
sections.text: Due to the agglutinative nature of language, the morphemes suffixes can be added in many different arbitrary sequences. Therefore, we have designed the FST as a generator, which means that the output of the FST is the surface form of a conjugated verb and the input is its lemmas and morphological characteristic. By its very nature, the FST has no knowledge of valid or invalid orders of these suffixes and therefore tends to overgenerate surface shapes for a particular input.When using the FST, it is trivial to reverse the direction of the FST and return the underlying form of the verb token. However, it is quite possible that a verb token has several forms of analysis and that it is left to the downstream application to decide between possible analyses.7.4 Adjective morphology phenomena are like adjectives (as described in § 4.3, there are two main classes of objective adaptors, and we use them to describe our analytics).

sections.heading: 8 Second System Analysis (verbs and adjectives)
sections.text: We extracted all the tokens that were marked as verbs or adjectives in the Tanaka corpus. Table 1 shows statistics on the verbal and adjective lexical elements in the corpus. From all the tokens we extracted 2,000 composite and 1,000 adjective tokens for manual evaluation. Since the FST produces multiple analyses for each token (there may also be several valid analyses without context), we measure the accuracy / recall performance of our analyst. Table 5 presents the results of our evaluation. Since our FST contains # correct analyses of analyses and recalls # of analyses and recalls # of analyses and recalls # of evaluation setI (# correct analyses > 0), Table 5 presents the results of our evaluation.

sections.text: See table 6 and 7 for example verbs and adjectives.

sections.heading: 9 Final Revisions
sections.text: Many of the erroneous analyses can be eliminated by simple heuristics. We have developed a post-processing recognition mechanism (instead of an FST) that uses the dictionary forms (tagmata) returned by MeCab and (ii) each of the different analyses we return as input. We decide whether the analyses contain 9 out of 11 (i) invalid orders of morphemes or (ii) match the dictionary forms returned by MeCab. We believe that this will help reduce the number of analyses generated per input and thus improve accuracy without compromising the callback.

sections.heading: 10 Future Work
sections.text: For future work, we propose the following improvements: (i) widening the coverage of verbal and adjective lexical elements, (ii) widening the coverage of the analyzer to include the use of t-shaped subjunctive verbs, (iii) widening the coverage of the adjective analyzer to include the use of rare adjectives and verb classes, and (iv) possibly more heuristics in post-processing to address overgenerations.10 of 11
